page.title:
Three Interpretations of Entropy
Three Interpretations of Entropy
page.enlisting:
• The amount of information an event provides – An infrequently occurring event provides more information • The uncertainty in the outcome of an event – Systems with one very common event have less entropy • The dispersion in the probability distribution – An image of a single amplitude has a less disperse • the lower dispersion implies lower entropy • The amount of information an event provides
• The amount of information an event provides
– An infrequently occurring event provides more information
– An infrequently occurring event provides more information
• The uncertainty in the outcome of an event
• The uncertainty in the outcome of an event
– Systems with one very common event have less entropy
– Systems with one very common event have less entropy
• The dispersion in the probability distribution
• The dispersion in the probability distribution
– An image of a single amplitude has a less disperse
– An image of a single amplitude has a less disperse
• the lower dispersion implies lower entropy
• the lower dispersion implies lower entropy
than a frequently occurring event
than a frequently occurring event
than systems with many equally probable events
than systems with many equally probable events

page.title:
Measures of Information
Measures of Information
page.enlisting:

page.title:
Entropy for Image Registration
Entropy for Image Registration
page.enlisting:
• Define estimate of joint probability distribution of images: – 2-D histogram where each axis designates the number of – each histogram cell is incremented each time a pair (I_1(x,y), – if images are perfectly aligned then the histogram is highly focused; as the images mis-align the dispersion grows – recall one interpretation of entropy is as a measure of histogram • Define estimate of joint probability distribution of images:

page.title:
Mutual Information for Image Registration
Mutual Information for Image
Registration
page.enlisting:
• Recall definition(s): – I(A,B) = H(B) - H(B|A) = H(A) - H(A|B) – I(A,B) = H(A) + H(B) - H(A,B) • Advantage in using mutual info over joint entropy is it includes the • Works better than simply joint entropy in regions of image • Mutual information is maximized for registered images • amount that uncertainty in B (or A) is reduced when A (or B) is known. • maximizing is equivalent to minimizing joint entropy (last term) • Recall definition(s): – I(A,B) = H(B) - H(B|A) = H(A) - H(A|B) – I(A,B) = H(A) + H(B) - H(A,B) • Advantage in using mutual info over joint entropy is it includes the • Works better than simply joint entropy in regions of image • Mutual information is maximized for registered images • Recall definition(s):

page.title:
Properties of Mutual Information
Properties of Mutual Information
page.enlisting:
• MI is symmetric: I(A,B) = I(B,A) • I(A,A) = H(A) • I(A,B) <= H(A), I(A,B) <= H(B) – info each image contains about the other cannot be greater than the info they themselves contain • I(A,B) >= 0 – Cannot increase uncertainty in A by knowing B • If A, B are independent then I(A,B) = 0 • If A, B are Gaussian then: • MI is symmetric: I(A,B) = I(B,A) • I(A,A) = H(A) • I(A,B) <= H(A), I(A,B) <= H(B)
• MI is symmetric: I(A,B) = I(B,A)
• I(A,A) = H(A)
• I(A,B) <= H(A), I(A,B) <= H(B)
– info each image contains about the other cannot be greater than the info they themselves contain

Mutual Information based Feature Selection
Mutual Information based Feature
Selection
page.footer:
• Tested both single M.I., and Joint M.I. (JMI)
• Tested both single M.I., and Joint M.I. (JMI)
page.enlisting:
• Tested using 2-class Occupant sensing problem – Classes are RFIS and everything else (children, – Use edge map of imagery and compute features • Legendre Moments to order 36 • Generates 703 features, we select best 51 features. • Tested 3 filter-based methods: – Mann-Whitney statistic – Kullback-Leibler statistic – Mutual Information criterion • Tested using 2-class Occupant sensing

Joint Mutual Information based Feature Selection Method

Feature Selection Method
page.enlisting:
• Joint M.I. tests a feature’s independence from all • Two implementations proposed: – 1) Compute all individual M.I.s and sort from high to low – Test the joint M.I of current feature with others kept • Keep the features with the lowest JMI (implies independence) • Implement by selecting features that maximize: • Joint M.I. tests a feature’s independence from all
